column1: #FORMAT=WebAnno TSV 3.3
#T_SP=custom.Span|label
#T_RL=custom.Relation|label|BT_custom.Span
#Text=This erroneous opinion appears to have been based on the effects
#Text=occasionally produced by the poison on animals: it is not in any
#Text=way supported by observations on man.
#Text=The evidence derivable from the taste and odour of this poison is,
#Text=in some instances, of importance.
#Text=The taste is described by Dr.
#Text=Christison as pungent ; some state that it is hot, others that it is
#Text=bitter.
#Text=(Pereira.)
#Text=In one fatal case (December 1856) deceased
#Text=complained, on swallowing about two drachms of the poison by
#Text=mistake, that it had a bitter taste.
#Text=When the common acid is mixed with organic liquids, a taste is not likely to be perceptible unless the dose is large.
#Text=With regard to the odour, Dr.
#Text=Christison states that when
#Text=diffused, it has a distant resemblance to that of bitter almonds ;
#Text=but it is accompanied with a peculiar impression of acridity on
#Text=the nostrils and back of the throat.
#Text=(Op. cit. 752.)
#Text=Orfila also
#Text=says that it is similar to that of bitter almonds : — this is, indeed,
#Text=the common impression.
#Text=There is, however, a difference between
#Text=these odours ; but the difference is not perceptible to the senses
#Text=of all, and the only practical point requiring notice is, that the
#Text=diluted odour of bitter almonds would probably be pronounced by
#Text=many persons to indicate the presence of prussic acid, especially
#Text=if there existed any suspicion of violent death.
#Text=Even experienced
#Text=medical men have to my knowledge been deceived on this point.
#Text=There are some who are unable to perceive the odour of prussic
#Text=acid when it exists in large proportion, whether mixed with water
#Text=or other liquids ; while others, again, are peculiarly susceptible
#Text=of it.
#Text=With some, it does not affect the olfactory nerves at all,
#Text=but produces merely a sense of constriction in the throat.
#Text=These
#Text=facts appear to me to explain, — why, on being called to a case of
#Text=poisoning by this acid, or during the examination of a body,
#Text=some medical men perceive the odour while others do not.
#Text=When many have to
#Text=form a judgment on this subject, it is much
#Text=more common to find disagreement than unanimity.
#Text=In a case
#Text=seen by Dr.
#Text=Christison, in which a man had swallowed a large
#Text=dose of prussic acid, there was no odour in the breath, near the
#Text=patient, nor in any part of the room.
#Text=Two persons could not
#Text=perceive any odour in six ounces of the warm fluid freshly
#Text=drawn from the stomach by the pump.
#Text=(Ed.
#Text=Month.
#Text=Journal,
#Text=On other occasions the odour may be concealed by peppermint, tobacco, or other odours.
#Text=In a case communicated to me in May 1850, by Mr.
#Text=Rake, a man swallowed
#Text=a large dose of prussic acid, and was observed walking and
#Text=smoking a pipe.
#Text=He was found dead in a privy very shortly
#Text=afterwards ; but although the body was still warm, the smell of
#Text=tobacco-smoke from the mouth completely overpowered and
#Text=concealed the odour of prussic acid.
#Text=On opening the body, the
#Text=smell of the acid was at once perceptible.
